review.title: Spotting Suspicious Link Behavior with fBox: An Adversarial Perspective
review.abstract: How can we detect suspicious users in large online networks? Online popularity of a user or product (via follows, page-likes, etc.) can be monetized on the premise of higher ad click-through rates or increased sales. Web services and social networks which incentivize popularity thus suffer from a major problem of fake connections from link fraudsters looking to make a quick buck. Typical methods of catching this suspicious behavior use spectral techniques to spot large groups of often blatantly fraudulent (but sometimes honest) users. However, small-scale, stealthy attacks may go unnoticed due to the nature of low-rank eigenanalysis used in practice.

INTRODUCTIONIn an online network, how can we distinguish honest users from fraudulent ones? Since many online services rely on machine learning algorithms to recommend relevant content to their users, it is crucial that user feedback is legitimate and indicative of true interests. "

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND AND RELATED WORK
sections.text: We begin with a detailed look at several current methods for detecting web fraud and spam. Table I shows a qualitative comparison between different methods for detecting link fraud.

sections.heading: A. Spectral methods
sections.text: We classify techniques that analyze the latent factors produced as spectral methods in graph-based self-analyses or matrix / tensor decomposition. These algorithms attempt to find patterns in graph decompositions in order to extract coherent groups of users or objects. Prakash et al's work on the eigenSpokes pattern [19] and Jiang et al's work on spectral subspaces of social networks [9] are two such approaches that we primarily focus on and that have been applied to real datasets to detect suspicious link behavior. [21] Using a similar analysis of spectral link patterns, we focus on random link attacks (RLAs) that exhibit properties other than link fraud and thus produce different patterns. This work utilizes the singular value decomposition (SVD) of the input graph graphs graphs graphs graphs graphs graphs graphs graphics graphs that focus on graph behavior, but not on graph-detect patterns.

sections.heading: B. Graph-traversal based methods
sections.text: A variety of algorithms have been proposed to traverse the graph directly to find or stop suspicious behavior. [20] offers a random walk algorithm to detect RLAs. [6] suggests a PageRank-like approach to punishing promiscuous users on Twitter, but unfortunately only proves effective in detecting spammers already caught rather than detecting new ones. [18] uses belief propagation to find near-bilateral cores of attackers on eBay.The most similar application, however, is Beutel et as a COPYCATCH algorithm to find suspicious lockstep behavior in Facebook page likes [3]. COPYCATCH is a clustering method that attempts to find densely connected groups in loud data by limited graph transgression, motivated by the intuition of scams that take the form of naively generated two-sided cores in the input graph.

sections.heading: C. Feature-based methods
sections.text: Detection of spam and fraud has traditionally been described as a function-based classification problem, based, for example, on the words in spam emails or URLs in tweets. [7] However, it focuses on malicious tweets and notes that approaches to blacklisting are too slow to curb the spread of Twitter spam. ODDBALL [1] proposes functions based on egonets to find abnormal users using weighted charts. [4] and [13] take a game theory approach to learning simple classifiers about generic traits to detect spam. Although these approaches are related from an adverse perspective, they focus on the general function-based classification as for spam email, rather than the graph analysis required to detect link fraud.

sections.heading: III. AN ADVERSARIAL ANALYSIS - OUR PERSPECTIVE
sections.text: In this section, we examine the exploitability of state-of-the-art methods from an opposing point of view, that is, we ignore the methods we use to detect the limitations of these methods. In particular, we use theoretical analyses to show that existing methods are highly vulnerable to attacks by intelligent attackers. Table II provides a comprehensive list of symbols and corresponding definitions used in our paper. Given the knowledge of the detection threshold used by a particular service, how can an attacker avoid intelligent attacks on this service in order to avoid detection by fraud methods? sections.heading: IV. PROPOSED FRAMEWORK FOR FRAUD BEHAVIORS
sections.text: As shown in Section III, current detection methods are effective for catching blatant attacks, but effectiveness decreases as the attack size decreases. Although the scale of detected attacks is differently defined for different sets of data, there is necessarily such a detection overlap point given the well-defined nature of the singular value generated by common attack types. In this section, we will give a more comprehensive overview of possible attack modes and the capabilities of current methods in dealing with them. Table IV shows how current techniques fit into our classification of suitable defenses against four different types of attack and how the proposed FBOX algorithm can fill the remaining holes to provide a more holistic framework for fraud detection. The four types of attacks we address in this work are classified on the basis of two densities - the scale of attack and the presence of camouflage patterns given above, the scale of attack is unrelated to the size of the attack, the scope of the scope of the attack, or the scope of the attack.

sections.heading: A. Blatant Attack/No Camouflage
sections.text: Of the four types, blatant attacks without camouflage are the easiest to detect. Blatant attacks with singular values above the threshold σk and therefore occurring in the precedence-k decomposition of spectral methods generate spoke-like patterns and can be identified with SPOKEN. It should be noted that SPOKEN is a method of filtering large communities out of graphics, and not necessarily attackers. In this case, a check of blatant lockstep behavior is required as fraudulent.

sections.heading: B. Blatant Attack/Camouflage
sections.text: Of course, blatant attacks with camouflage are more difficult to detect than without. Although the singular values of the attacks are above the threshold σk and the associated singular vectors occur in the simple decomposition of spectral methods, Jiang et al. showed that the spectral subspace diagrams had tilting beams instead of axial spokes. COPYCATCH is also effective in detecting blatant attacks with camouflage (provided the parameter selection is sufficiently large to limit the rate of false positive parameters), since camouflage is ignored in the case that an m, n, p nearly two-sided nucleus is found for a subset of U and P for a fixed snapshot of the input graph.

sections.heading: C. Stealth Attack/No Camouflage
sections.text: As noted in Section III, current detection systems are highly vulnerable to covert attacks designed to fall below the parameter thresholds of σk for spectral methods or m, n, p for cluster methods. To our knowledge, no previous technology has been able to successfully and effectively identify users involved in this type of attack. Although covert attacks may be of less importance individually than major fraud cases, they have the insidious ability to achieve the same number of fraudulent actions in a more controlled and less detectable manner, at the expense of creating more fraudulent accounts. In response to this threat, we propose the FBOX algorithm for identifying such attacks in Section V and demonstrate its effectiveness in Section VI.

sections.heading: D. Stealth Attack/Camouflage
sections.text: Given that the identification of small attacks has been an open problem for fraud detection, the problem of identifying these attacks with disguise has not been addressed either. The difficulty of dealing with camouflage is particularly evident when looking at user accounts with few outgoing or incoming links, as is typically the case with smaller attacks. From a user's perspective, it may seem that a truly fraudulent account is mostly honest, but with a few suspicious or uncharacteristic links (which are not enough to be labeled fraudulent) or is rarely / rashly used due to the small number of total links.

sections.heading: V. PROPOSED ALGORITHM
sections.text: Given this problem, it is natural to consider the following question - how can we identify the many small attacks that tend to slip under the radar of existing techniques? In this section, we formalize our problem definition and propose FBOX as the appropriate method to solve this problem.

sections.text: For our experiments, we primarily use two datasets: the who-follows-who Twitter graph and the who-rates-what Amazon graph. (The Twitter graph was scraped by Kwak et al. in March 2013 and contains 41.7 million users with 1.5 billion edges [11]. We showed the distribution of the suspicious values in Figure 3a. Our analysis is performed both directly and via synthetic attacks. B. FBOX on real Twitter accounts To show our effectiveness in capturing smart link fraud attacks on real data, we performed a classification of data from the Twitter graph. Specifically, we collected the results for suspicious fans and idols with a grade of at least 20 (to avoid catching unused accounts) for seven different values of the detection threshold.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we approached the problem of distinguishing dishonest attackers and their customers from honest users in the context of charts of online social networks or web services using a graph-based approach (using the Adjazency Matrix, which represents user-object relationships). Our main contributions are: 1) Theoretical Analysis: We examine several modern methods for detecting fraud from an opposite perspective, and provide theoretical results regarding the vulnerability of these methods to various types of attack. 2) FBOX Algorithm: We describe FBOX, a method that is motivated to address the blind spots discovered in theoretical analysis, in order to uncover a class of clandestine attacks that previous methods could not effectively detect. 3) Real Data Effectiveness: We apply FBOX to a large Twitter follower-sem dataset from 2010 and discover many tens of thousands of suspicious users whose accounts remain active for data.

metadata.abstractText: How can we detect suspicious users in large online networks? Online popularity of a user or product (via follows, page-likes, etc.) can be monetized on the premise of higher ad click-through rates or increased sales. Web services and social networks which incentivize popularity thus suffer from a major problem of fake connections from link fraudsters looking to make a quick buck. Typical methods of catching this suspicious behavior use spectral techniques to spot large groups of often blatantly fraudulent (but sometimes honest) users. However, small-scale, stealthy attacks may go unnoticed due to the nature of low-rank eigenanalysis used in practice. In this work, we take an adversarial approach to find and prove claims about the weaknesses of modern, state-of-the-art spectral methods and propose FBOX, an algorithm designed to catch small-scale, stealth attacks that slip below the radar. Our algorithm has the following desirable properties: (a) it has theoretical underpinnings, (b) it is shown to be highly effective on real data and (c) it is scalable (linear on the input size). We evaluate FBOX on a large, public 41.7 million node, 1.5 billion edge who-follows-whom social graph from Twitter in 2010 and with high precision identify many suspicious accounts which have persisted without suspension even to this day.
